answers.answer: HiWelcome to the MedHelp forum!Since it is often happening at night, you need to rule out hypoglycemia and gastric reflux or GERD. Both can cause numbness and tingling of tongue and chin. It could also be due to diabetes.It could also be due to nerve compression very high up in the cervical vertebra. Excess alcohol intake, partial seizures and low calcium levels all cause head and tongue tingling. Wisdom tooth is another cause. Impacted one can cause tingling, numbness and jaw pain.It is difficult to comment beyond this at this stage. The enumerated the possibilities can be investigated or ruled out one by one by your physician.Hope this helps. Please let me know if there is any thing else and do keep me posted. Take care!

question: please help me... i have been so desperate to find an answer ..it all started  2 months ago  when i woke up in the middle of the night felling like i was having a heart attack...eneded up in the ER ...docs found nothing...after nemerous trips to the doc and hospital all they thought was either i was getting anxiety attacks or i had a virus....i have gotten everything done eeg ...vng...ambulatory eeg...stress test etc...scheduled for an MRI of the brain next week.....i have similar episodes of the attacks at times in the middle of the night....THE BIGGEST PROBLEB IS NUMBNESS AND TINGLING OF THE TONGUE CHIN ALONG WITH PAIN IN THE JAW VERY FREQUENTLY>>>> PLEASE HELP IF ANYONE HAS HAD SIMILAR PROBLEMS
title: numbness and tingling of tonue and chin
